home.title: Welcome to datacat
home.about.title: About the Project
home.about.description: The datacat platform is a cross-project research effort by the Department of 'Geodesy and BIM' at the Faculty of Geoinformation at the University of Applied Sciences Dresden (HTW Dresden). The platform aims to provide user- and developer-friendly components for the creation and publication of classification systems, object catalogs, and property databases in the context of the BIM methodology.
home.components.title: The Components
home.components.description: The platform is currently divided into the core components datacat API, a developer-friendly, self-documenting GraphQL interface for complex queries on the data catalog, and the datacat editor, a browser-based user tool for navigating and editing the data.
home.methodology.title: The Methodology
home.methodology.description: The core of the development is a data schema closely aligned with established standards DIN EN ISO 12006-3 and DIN EN ISO 23387, which should make it possible to maintain even complex classification systems in the catalog. The API is completely agnostic regarding the application-specific structure to be implemented in the data catalog.
home.opensource.title: Open Source
home.opensource.description: datacat is developed as free and open-source software under the GPLv3 license and can be freely used and distributed, including commercially. The source code is hosted on GitHub. Any form of support for the project is welcome.

intro.description1: datacat editor is a web-based, open-source tool for collaboratively developing data catalogs for the construction industry. The source code is available under the GPL v3 license.
intro.description2: In a data catalog, you can name, describe, and categorize concepts such as actors, activities, building elements, and properties in multiple languages according to their function and form. By creating relationships between these concepts, the built environment can ultimately be described in more detail.
intro.description3: The developed dataset is available for retrieval via an API for developers of import/export tools and CAD/BIM plugins. In the future, validation routines will be developed to identify inconsistencies such as unused concepts, possible duplicates, and missing translations in the catalog.
intro.description4: datacat is developed at the University of Applied Sciences Dresden (HTW Dresden). If you are interested in the project or have questions about the application, please feel free to contact us directly using the details provided below.
intro.call_to_action: Your direct involvement as an open-source developer or indirect support through feedback is highly appreciated.

import.heading: Import catalog (CSV)
import.description: On this page, entities and their relationships can be imported. As with export, two CSV files can be imported here. One file contains the entities in the following schema:
import.entity_columns_note: Columns marked with o can optionally contain values.
import.tags_note: To make the entities visible in the datacat editor interface, they must be given tags from the taxonomy chosen there. (Reference document, Dictionary, Theme, Class, Property group, Property, Value list, Value, Unit of measurement)
import.relation_columns_note: The other file optionally contains the relationships between entities with the following columns:
import.note_entities_only: NOTE: Only entities, not relationships between them, will be imported!
import.note_relations_only: NOTE: Only relationships will be imported. The entities must already exist in the property server!
import.error_columns_mismatch: The column names do not match the specification.

import_excel.heading: Import catalog (Excel table)
import_excel.description: On this page, entities and their relationships can also be imported. Unlike the CSV import, an external Excel table can be used. For the import to work, the columns must be specified correctly in which the respective entities are listed: Reference document, Dictionary, Theme, Class, Property, Value list, Unit of measurement, and Value.
import_excel.label: Label
import_excel.name: Name
import_excel.validation_failed: Validation failed. Please check the error messages.
import_excel.validation_success: Validation successful. You can now import the Excel file.

create_entry_form.description_helper: Describe the concept in its meaning. Use the description especially to distinguish it from possibly similarly named but technically different concepts.
create_entry_form.comment_helper: Leave a comment on this concept. Additional information can be exchanged between editors here.
create_entry_form.languageOfCreator_helper: The language in which the concept was created.
create_entry_form.countryOfOrigin_helper: The country in which the concept was created.
create_entry_form.id_helper: The ID is usually generated automatically. An ID can be specified if it has already been assigned to the concept in a higher-level context.
create_entry_form.dictionary_helper: The dictionary in which the concept is created. A concept can only be created in one dictionary.
create_entry_form.name_duplicate_hint: Note: This name is already taken. You can still save the concept.

delete_import_view.description: Entities with a specific tag can be deleted here. All relationships attached to the entities will also be deleted.

export_view.heading: Export catalog as CSV
export_view.description:
The following button starts the download of a ZIP file containing two CSV files.
The file 'Entities.csv' contains all catalog entries with their metadata.
The file 'Relationships.csv' stores the relationships between the catalog entries.
The resulting file is encoded in UTF-8, uses comma (,) as a separator, and double quotes (") as text qualifier.
The data is ready for export as soon as the button is no longer grayed out.
export_view.description_ontology:
The ontology export currently includes all classes, properties, value lists, and values. It is important for the ontology export that the names of the concepts are unique to avoid errors. To ensure this, the verification tools can be used.
The ontology can be exported using either German or English names as identifiers.

tag_view.heading: Existing tags
tag_view.explanation: This page is used to add new tags to the database. The tags can then be used in the table view to add new tags to the existing entries.

info.selection_help: Select from the existing properties in datacat those that should belong to this new IFC Propertyset. This Propertyset will only be used locally for IDS creation and will not be saved in the datacat property server.

notifications.name_required: Please enter a name for the new IFC Propertyset.

ids_name.title: IDS Name - Help
ids_name.content:
The IDS Name is the main title of your Information Delivery Specification.

This name will be:
• Used as the title in the generated IDS XML file
• Used as filename when downloading (special characters will be removed)
• Used for identification when saving and loading

Tip: Choose a meaningful name like 'Structural-Check-2024' or 'Fire-Safety-Requirements'.

ids_version.title: IDS Version - Help
ids_version.content:
The IDS Version is the version number of your specific IDS file (not the schema version).

Examples:
• '1.0' for the first version
• '2.1' for a revised version
• '3.0-beta' for a beta version

This version is stored in the <ids:version> element of the XML file and helps with version control of your IDS specifications.

ifc_versions.title: IFC Versions - Help
ifc_versions.content:
Select the IFC versions for which this IDS specification should apply.

Available versions:
• IFC2X3: Older version, still widely used
• IFC4: Current standard version
• IFC4X3: Latest version with extended features

You can select multiple versions if your specification is compatible with different IFC versions.

specification_name.title: Specification Name - Help
specification_name.content:
The name of the individual specification within your IDS file.

An IDS file can contain multiple specifications. Each specification checks specific aspects of your BIM models.

Examples:
• 'Check wall properties'
• 'Validate fire protection classes'
• 'Verify structural elements'

The name should clearly describe what this specification validates.

applicability.title: Applicability - Help
applicability.content:
Applicability defines which BIM objects this specification applies to.

🏗️ Type (IFC Class):
• Refers to specific IFC object types (e.g. walls, doors, windows)
• You can select multiple IFC classes
• Example: IFCWALL, IFCDOOR, IFCWINDOW

🏷️ Classification:
• Refers to classified objects (e.g. according to DIN 276, OMNICLASS)
• Uses IFCCLASSIFICATION as IFC class
• Example: Objects with specific cost groups or functional classes

ifc_classes.title: IFC Classes - Help
ifc_classes.content:
Select the IFC entity types this specification applies to.

Commonly used classes:
• IFCWALL - Walls
• IFCDOOR - Doors
• IFCWINDOW - Windows
• IFCSLAB - Slabs/Floor plates
• IFCBEAM - Beams
• IFCCOLUMN - Columns
• IFCSPACE - Spaces

You can select multiple classes if the same requirements apply to different object types.

Tip: Use the search function to quickly find the desired IFC classes.

requirements.title: Requirements - Help
requirements.content:
Requirements define what properties the selected objects must have.

🏷️ Classification:
• Checks classification values (e.g. cost groups, functional classes)
• Select the classification system and optionally specific classes

📝 Attribute:
• Checks IFC attributes of objects
• Example: Name, Description, or other direct object properties

🔧 Property:
• Checks PropertySets and their properties
• Example: Fire resistance class, U-value, material type
• You can define multiple properties and their allowed values

Each requirement can be marked as 'required', 'optional', or 'prohibited'.

classification_system.title: Classification System - Help
classification_system.content:
Select the model or reference document that defines the classification.

This can be:
• A cost breakdown system (e.g. DIN 276)
• A functional classification system
• A manufacturer-specific classification system
• A project-specific reference document

The selected system is used as 'System' in the IDS classification.

property_group.title: Property Group (PropertySet) - Help
property_group.content:
PropertySets are groups of related properties in IFC.

Examples:
• Pset_WallCommon - Common wall properties
• Pset_DoorCommon - Common door properties
• Pset_SpaceFireSafetyRequirements - Fire safety requirements for spaces

You can:
• Select existing PropertySets from the catalog
• Create new PropertySets with the ➕ button
• Select multiple properties from one PropertySet

The URI is automatically generated and references the definition in the catalog.

datatype.title: Data Type - Help
datatype.content:
The data type defines what kind of values are expected for this property.

Common data types:
• IFCLABEL - Short text (e.g. material name)
• IFCTEXT - Longer text (e.g. description)
• IFCBOOLEAN - Yes/No values (e.g. load bearing)
• IFCREAL - Decimal numbers (e.g. U-value: 0.24)
• IFCINTEGER - Whole numbers (e.g. count: 5)
• IFCLENGTHMEASURE - Length measures (e.g. 2.5m)
• IFCAREAMEASURE - Area measures (e.g. 25.5m²)

The data type is optional but recommended for precise validation.

cardinality.title: Cardinality - Help
cardinality.content:
Cardinality determines whether a property must be present.

✅ Required:
• The property MUST be present
• Objects without this property are invalid
• Default setting for most requirements

❓ Optional:
• The property CAN be present
• If present, it must match the defined values
• If not present, the object is still valid

❌ Prohibited:
• The property MUST NOT be present
• Objects with this property are invalid
• Useful for exclusion rules

property_values.title: Property Values - Help
property_values.content:
Here you can define specific values for the selected property.

🎯 Usage:
• Define allowed values for this property
• Multiple selection possible for alternative values
• Examples: REI30, REI60, REI90 for fire resistance classes

📋 Value Enumeration:
• All selected values are defined as allowed options in the IDS
• The object must have one of these values to be valid
• Empty selection means: Any value is allowed (only property must be present)

metadata.defaultDescription: Generated IDS specification for building information validation
